Though it was a terrible thing
 Pilate and Judas Iscariot one spirit in the same 
 But the sacrifice was not in vain
 Nor the Jews should one blame
 Had not God ordained this thing
 Blinding Jewish eye's that day
 Which sinner amongst us could be saved?

He made the world for us to live,
 And to us life he loved to give.
 But ADAM sinned on one day,
 And by THAT action did God say;
 You, of the earth you will toil and sweat,
 You can't live without me I'd like to bet.
 
 Jehovah teaches people well,
 And gives them a nation in which to dwell.
 All the peace and all security,
 Is in my hand to give to thee.
 All I ask is you follow my law,
 And your salvation is at the door.
 
 Why are you disloyal to me?
 I'm here to help you can't you see.
 Here the messiah is sent to you,
 To teach about me and look what you do.
 I've had my fill with this wayward nation,
 The law will change by my operation.
 
 Preach and teach in every land,
 Bring all the meek into my hand.
 Follow my law in desperate times,
 I can't believe this poem rhymes.
 Some will fall and some will err,
 It amazes me that they do not care.
 
 When the time is right I'll bring you back,
 A Christian organization that does not lack.
 You will preach and teach on a global scale,
 And bring tears of joy to the old and frail.
 Some will hate you and even kill,
 Because you are the people that love my will.
 
 Teach the Bible and in the truth remain,
 Reprove teachers whom my name profane.
 Time is short I'm coming soon,
 Over all the earth will peace be strewn.
 A world accomplished for divine fitness,
 ALL MY LOVE, a loyal witness.

 I thought that exact same thing, but then i remembered this parable
 From 'Insight on the Scriptures' pg. 1183
 (26) The murderous cultivators (Mt 21:33-44; Mr 12:1-11; Lu 20:9-18). Spoken in the temple in Jerusalem, just three days before Jesus, God's Son, was killed. This illustration, too, was in answer to the question about the source of Jesus' authority. (Mr 11:27-33) Immediately after the illustration, the Gospel accounts state that the religious leaders realized that he was speaking about them.-Mt 21:45; Mr 12:12; Lu 20:19.
 The fence around the vineyard might have been of stone (Pr 24:30, 31) or it might have been a hedge. (Isa 5:5) The wine vat was frequently excavated in the rock and consisted of two levels, the juice flowing from the upper one to the lower. The tower was a lookout place for the guard, who was to keep out thieves and animals. In some cases, the cultivators employed received a certain portion of the fruits. In other cases, the cultivators paid rent in money or agreed to give the owner a definite amount of the produce, the latter apparently being the case in the illustration. By murdering the son, the heir, they may have thought to seize the vineyard as their own, since the one who planted it was out of the country. In Isaiah 5:1-7 "the vineyard of Jehovah" is said to be "the house of Israel." As shown by the Gospel writers, Jesus quoted Psalm 118:22, 23 as a key to understanding the illustration.

 And then, according to traditional Christian beliefs, he arose from the dead.

Yes, he was -- according to the Christian faith. He was, in fact, killed. Physically dead.

And then, according to traditional Christian beliefs, he arose from the dead.

 God let the part of him that was Jesus stand back up and walk among man for awhile longer.

The issue is probably not monocausational. While Jesus had many Jewish followers (in fact, nearly all of the original followers were Jewish), there were evidently some Jews who did not have such a favorable view of him and likely wanted him executed. Nonetheless, it was the Romans who put the nails in his body and crucified him, thus it was the Romans who actually killed him. Pilate could have chosen not to execute him but in the end yielded to the will of the mob, fearing a riot. Also, we can't forget the role of Judas Iscariot. Satan (if he exists) also played a role of influence.

Also, we can't forget the role of Judas Iscariot. Satan (if he exists) also played a role of influence.

 
 But if God needed Jesus to die, then Judas was doing God's bidding. It is possible that Judas was the only one that God could rely on for this very important task of ensuring his arrest by the Romans. And if that is the case, then how is God's will and God's plan some kind of influence by Satan?
 
 If God needed Jesus to be crucified, if that was the plan all along, then everything that leads towards this is part of God's bidding, not anybody else's.

But if God needed Jesus to die, then Judas was doing God's bidding. It is possible that Judas was the only one that God could rely on for this very important task of ensuring his arrest by the Romans. And if that is the case, then how is God's will and God's plan some kind of influence by Satan?
 

 
 One could argue that Satan influenced Judas Iscariot to betray Jesus. Perhaps he just wanted to see God (incarnated in the form of a Jewish carpenter) to suffer, or perhaps Satan was ignorant of God's plan. Who knows?
